poem:
Breaking Point

In cells, shadows stretch—  
a sea of iron beds,  
where breath is measured  
by brick and bar.

Governors tally heads,  
as walls whisper  
to the incoming tide  
of men, souls pressing  
against the brittle edge  
of hope,  
breaking not with a roar  
but the quiet crumble  
of rusted steel and  
silent cries.
